raw_text:
More power to the people says HP
 
 The digital revolution is focused on letting people tell and share their own stories, according to Carly Fiorina, chief of technology giant Hewlett Packard.
 
 The job of firms such as HP now, she said in a speech at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), was to ensure digital and physical worlds fully converged. She said the goal for 2005 was to make people the centre of technology. CES showcases 50,000 new gadgets that will be hitting the shelves in 2005. The tech-fest, the largest of its kind in the world, runs from 6 to 9 January. "The digital revolution is about the democratisation of technology and the experiences it makes possible," she told delegates. "Revolution has always been about giving power to the people." She added: "The real story of the digital revolution is not just new products, but the millions of experiences made possible and stories that millions can tell." Part of giving people more control has been about the freeing up of content, such as images, video and music. Crucial to this has been the effort to make devices that speak to each other better so that content can be more easily transferred from one device, such as a digital camera, to others, such as portable media players. A lot of work still needs to be done, however, to sort out compatibility issues and standards within the technology industry so that gadgets just work seamlessly, she said.
 
 Ms Fiorina's talk also touted the way technology is being designed to focus on lifestyle, fashion and personalisation, something she sees as key to what people want.
 
 Special guest, singer Gwen Stefani, joined her on-stage to promote her own range of HP digital cameras which Ms Stefani has helped design and which are heavily influenced by Japanese youth culture. The digital cameras, which are due to go on sale in the US by the summer, are based on the HP 607 model. The emphasis on personalisation and lifestyle is a big theme at this year's CES, with tiny, wearable MP3 players at every turn and rainbow hues giving colour to everything. Ms Fiorina also announced that HP was working with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles, which would launch in Europe early this year. The service will let people listen to radio on their mobiles and download relevant content, like a track's ringtone, simultaneously. The service is designed to make mobile radio more interactive.
 
 Among the other new products she showcased was the Digital Media Hub, a big upgrade to HP's Digital Entertainment Centre. Coming out in the autumn in the US, the box is a networked, high-definition TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder and DVD recorder. It has a removable hard drive cartridge, memory card slots, and Light Scribe labelling software which lets people design and print customised DVD labels and covers. It is designed to contain all a household's digital media, such as pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, videos and music so it can all be managed in one place. The hub reflects the increasing move to re-box the PC so that it can work as part of other key centres of entertainment. Research suggests that about 258 million images are saved and shared every day, equating to 94 billion a year. Eighty per cent of those remain on cameras. Media hubs are designed to encourage people to organise them on one box. Ms Fiorina was one of several keynote speakers, who also included Microsoft chief Bill Gates, to set out what major technology companies think people will be doing with technologies and gadgets in the next 12 months. In a separate announcement during the keynote speech, Ms Fiorina said that HP would be partnering MTV to replace this year's MTV Asia music award. MTV's Asia Aid will be held in Bangkok on 3 February, and is aimed at helping to raise money for the Asian tsunami disaster.
llama3.2:1b: HP CEO Carly Fiorina says more power should go to people and digital technology should converge with physical worlds. Her goal for 2005 was to make people the center of technology, with CES showcasing 50,000 new gadgets. She emphasizes the democratization of technology and its ability to create millions of experiences. Devices are being made better connected so content can be transferred easily. Technology is shifting towards lifestyle, fashion, and personalisation. The HP 607 camera is a recent example of this focus on design.
llama3.2:3b: HP chief Carly Fiorina says digital revolution aims to make people the centre of technology, giving power to the people through democratisation of technology and experiences it makes possible. She highlights the importance of content transfer between devices, lifestyle focus, fashion, and personalisation in tech design, as well as new products like digital cameras and a visual radio service for mobiles.
gemma2:2b:
HP believes technology should empower individuals to share their stories. The company aims to create a world where digital and physical worlds converge and people are at the center of technology.  Their focus includes:

* Democratization of technology and experiences.
* Increasing content accessibility through device interoperability.
* Personalization, fashion, and lifestyle integration in technology design. 
* Collaboration with Nokia on visual radio service for mobile devices.
* Launch of the Digital Media Hub to manage all household digital media in one central location.


These initiatives are reflected in keynote addresses by HP leadership and a partnership with MTV for a donation-focused music event.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Carly Fiorina of Hewlett Packard emphasizes the importance of empowering people with digital technologies by focusing on their experiences rather than products, emphasizing a more lifestyle-oriented approach to technology, promoting wearable devices like HP cameras, and launching services to personalize and enhance entertainment options. The company showcased new products that integrate into existing household equipment like HP Digital Entertainment Centers and TV/CD/DVD boxes designed for media management and personalization.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Hewlett Packard CEO Carly Fiorina emphasizes the digital revolution empowering people by making technology more accessible and facilitating seamless content transfer between devices. She highlights lifestyle-focused tech design, including personalization and multimedia integration, while also announcing a partnership with Nokia for a visual radio service on mobiles. The summit features innovative gadgets showcasing the next generation of digital entertainment and media hubs.
qwen2.5:3b: More power to the people says HP. Digital revolution aims to let users tell their own stories, with firms like HP focusing on making digital and physical worlds converge. HP's goal by 2005 was to center technology around users. Key aspects include freeing up content such as images, video, and music, improving device compatibility, and personalization in product design. At CES, HP showcased new products like its Digital Media Hub for managing media in one place, and a visual radio service for mobiles. The conference also featured announcements about collaborations with Nokia and MTV, including replacing this year’s MTV Asia music awards to help raise funds for the Asian tsunami disaster.
opencoder:1.5b:
HP has stated a more "digital revolution" with its emphasis on personalisation, lifestyle, fashion and mobile radio services.

The talk by Carly Fiorina highlighted HP's vision of making technology accessible to everyone, not just tech-savvy individuals. She described the freeing up of content that can be easily transferred from one device, such as a digital camera, to others, like portable media players.

Gwen Stefani introduced her range of HP digital cameras which are heavily influenced by Japanese youth culture. The CES showcased various products like tiny wearable MP3 players and rainbow hues that give color to everything.

The Digital Media Hub was announced to make it easier for people to organize their digital media. Research shows that about 258 million images are saved and shared every day, equating to nearly 94 billion a year.

HP was also working with Nokia in Europe, aiming to make mobile radio more interactive. Keynote speakers were mentioned along with Microsoft chief Bill Gates as they contributed to this new tech landscape.

Crucial to this has been the effort to make devices that speak to each other better so that content can be more easily transferred from one device, such as a digital camera, to others, such as portable media players. Ms Fiorina was one of several keynote speakers, who also included Microsoft chief Bill Gates, to set out what major technology companies think people will be doing with technologies and gadgets in the next 12 months. The event is expected to raise money for the Asian tsunami disaster.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to create a summary of this text about the digital revolution by HP. Let me read through it carefully first.

So, the main points are: HP is emphasizing power at the people's hands because of the digital revolution. They want everyone to tell and share their stories in the digital world. They're talking at CES 2005, which showcases a lot of gadgets.

They mention that giving more control over content is part of this. Images, video, and music are being transferred between devices like digital cameras and portable media players. There's a lot to do with making these transfers seamless, so the tech needs standardization.

HP has been focusing on personalization and lifestyle products. They have digital cameras influenced by Japanese culture, with MP3 players at every turn and rainbow hues for color. They're also working with Nokia on a visual radio service that makes radio interactive on mobile phones.

They introduced something called the Digital Media Hub in the US, which is a big storage system for all their digital media, including TV shows, pictures, videos, and music. This hub helps people manage their stuff together instead of keeping everything separate. According to research, 258 million images are saved daily, with 94 billion over a year. Most of that is on cameras.

HP is pairing with Microsoft and another big tech company, maybe? Bill Gates is also speaking as a keynote speaker alongside Carly Fiorina. They're talking about what people will be doing next month with these technologies.

In summary, HP is leading the digital revolution by making sure everyone has control over their stories, sharing content easily, personalizing products, using visuals, and working together in tech hubs.
</think>

HP is leading the digital revolution by ensuring that everyone can tell, share, and manage stories through technology. They emphasize power at the people's hands, aiming to make the digital world fully cohesive. Through innovative products like digital cameras influenced by Japanese youth culture, they focus on personalization and lifestyle, using content from images, videos, music, and photos. Their Digital Media Hub in the US is a central storage system for all media, helping people organize their content together. They're also working with companies to make tech more interactive, such as a visual radio service on mobile phones. With Bill Gates speaking alongside, they highlight future trends, aiming to shape digital experiences for the next twelve months.
tinyllama:1.1b: In her speech at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in January 2005, HP CEO Dr. Carly Fiorina emphasized that digital technology is becoming more focused on experiences and stories rather than just new products. She discussed how the digital revolution has given power to people through freeing up content, and how technologies such as digital cameras and MP3 players are being designed to focus on life style, fashion, and personalization. Additionally, Dr. Fiorina announced that HP was working with NokiA to launch a visual radio service for mobile devices and the Digital Media Hub, a high-definition TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder, DVD recorders, and memory card slots to manage all users' media in one place. She further discussed the potential for future technologies such as media hubs that organize people's media on one box and encourage people to share them.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Digital Revolution: Focuses on the democratisation of technology and the experiences it makes possible.
phi:2.7b: Carly Fiorina, chief technology of Hewlett Packard (HP), spoke about the digital revolution focusing on people telling their own stories and said that HP's job was to make sure physical and digital worlds converged. She mentioned that the goal for 2005 was to give power to people through democratisation of technology, making it possible for millions to tell their experiences. The digital revolution is also about freedom of content, like images, video, and music, which have become easily transferrable between devices with better compatibility. Ms Fiorina emphasized the need to design technology around lifestyle and personalisation. She mentioned Gwen Stefani, who helped design HP's new range of digital cameras inspired by Japanese youth culture. The talk also discussed wearable MP3 players at CES, a visual radio service for mobiles in Europe, and the Digital Media Hub, which is a networked high-definition TV, cable set-top box, DVR, and DVD recorder with customisable DVD covers. HP's media hubs are designed to contain all household digital media so they can be managed in one place. Ms Fiorina was one of several keynote speakers who discussed what people will do with technology in the next year. She announced that HP would partner with MTV to replace this year's MTV Asia music award, which is aimed at helping raise money for the Asian tsunami disaster.
orca-mini:3b: HP's Carly Fiorina says the digital revolution is about giving power to the people, focusing on lifestyle and personalization. The company is working with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles.
hermes3:3b: HP says digital revolution aims to give power to people by letting them tell and share their own stories through technology, making them centre of technology by 2005.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Carly Fiorina, CEO of Hewlett Packard (HP), highlighted the focus of HP's digital revolution on letting people tell and share their own stories at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES). She emphasized the importance of convergence between the digital and physical worlds and noted that by 2005, people would be at the center of technology. The success of this endeavor required firms like HP to ensure devices could effectively communicate with one another, as well as address compatibility issues within the technology industry. Fiorina also discussed how technology is being designed with lifestyle, fashion, and personalization in mind. Additionally, she announced partnerships with Nokia for a visual radio service launch on mobile phones and collaborations with MTV for this year's MTV Asia music awards replacement.
chatgpt-4o-latest: HP's CEO Carly Fiorina emphasized at CES that the digital revolution is about empowering people by enabling them to share their own stories. She highlighted HP's goal of merging digital and physical worlds, making technology more user-centric. A key focus is improving device compatibility to facilitate seamless content sharing. Fiorina also stressed the importance of personalization, lifestyle, and fashion in technology. Singer Gwen Stefani joined her to promote HP digital cameras inspired by Japanese youth culture. HP announced a partnership with Nokia for a visual radio service and introduced the Digital Media Hub, a device integrating TV, DVR, and media storage. Fiorina also revealed HP's collaboration with MTV for Asia Aid, supporting tsunami relief efforts.
stablelm2:1.6b: Hewlett Packard's (HP) CEO Carly Fiorina emphasizes that the digital revolution aims to empower people by allowing them to share their personal stories. HP's role is to ensure a fully converged digital and physical world for users. Fiorina discusses the goal of making people the center of technology, citing experiences as key aspects of the digital revolution. Devices are increasingly designed to focus on lifestyle, fashion, and personalization, with tiny wearable MP3 players being a trend at this year's CES. HP is working with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles, set to launch in Europe early next year, allowing users to listen to radio on their mobiles and download relevant content simultaneously. The Digital Media Hub, a networked high-definition TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder, and DVD recorder, will be released in the autumn in the US.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Carly Fiorina, HP's CEO, emphasized at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) that the digital revolution prioritizes enabling people to create, share, and experience their own stories across both digital and physical realms. She outlined 2005's goals for HP: making technology centered around users. The event showcases 50,000 new gadgets, including cameras, portable media players, and the Digital Media Hub, a networked, high-definition entertainment center. This hub will store, organize, and allow playback of various digital content, such as TV shows, photos, videos, and music, in one centralized location.

Key features include:
- Removable hard drive cartridge for media storage
- Memory card slots for expanded capacity
- Light Scribe labeling software for custom DVD labels and covers
- Integration with other entertainment centers like TVs

Fiorina highlighted the importance of seamless device connectivity, content sharing, and personalization. She also announced HP's partnership with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles in Europe, enhancing user interaction with mobile radio. Additionally, Fiorina emphasized HP's collaboration with MTV to host the 2005 MTV Asia Awards, raising funds for Asian tsunami relief efforts.
reference: She said the goal for 2005 was to make people the centre of technology.Among the other new products she showcased was the Digital Media Hub, a big upgrade to HP's Digital Entertainment Centre.The digital revolution is focused on letting people tell and share their own stories, according to Carly Fiorina, chief of technology giant Hewlett Packard."The digital revolution is about the democratisation of technology and the experiences it makes possible," she told delegates.Ms Fiorina was one of several keynote speakers, who also included Microsoft chief Bill Gates, to set out what major technology companies think people will be doing with technologies and gadgets in the next 12 months.The job of firms such as HP now, she said in a speech at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), was to ensure digital and physical worlds fully converged.Media hubs are designed to encourage people to organise them on one box."Revolution has always been about giving power to the people."Part of giving people more control has been about the freeing up of content, such as images, video and music.Ms Fiorina's talk also touted the way technology is being designed to focus on lifestyle, fashion and personalisation, something she sees as key to what people want.It is designed to contain all a household's digital media, such as pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, videos and music so it can all be managed in one place.The digital cameras, which are due to go on sale in the US by the summer, are based on the HP 607 model.
